author: arnetheduck
content: how are execution clients handling the case where there's no suggested fee recipient?

author: sky.cactus
content: Isn't it a required field?

author: nishant0
content: In that case, its just burnt, no ?

author: arnetheduck
content: well - sort of but there's nothing forcing execution clients to use it - ie it would be quite .. reasonable for an execution client to have an override or default in certain cases - it could also be that the CL specifies a known-invalid address (like all-zeroes) in which case .. yeah, as <@476250636548308992> points out, it would get burnt - I'm just curious about the UX considerations here, and what the latest discussion points on this topic are

author: sky.cactus
content: I mean I thought the CL was *required* to provide a value, and the EL could decide what to do with it?

author: arnetheduck
content: indeed - it's part of the fork choice update call afair - but there's quite a few things that can go wrong here, also on the CL side, in terms of configuration leading to it having a nonsensical value

author: sky.cactus
content: I would say that as long as there is a number, it is fine from the EL's point of view, even if it doesn't make sense.

author: sky.cactus
content: Er, 160-bit number encoded however it is supposed to be encoded.

author: sky.cactus
content: The key thing to understand is whether the EL can rely on it receiving the value (failing hard if it doesn't) or if they need to have a code path for handling the missing case.

author: tersec
content: If it's not there, it's just an incorrectly formatted https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/blob/main/src/engine/specification.md#engine_forkchoiceupdatedv1 -- it's part of the `PayloadAttributesV1` structure. So it's never exactly missing, just potentially not valid.

author: tersec
content: as in, some nonsensical address. It's going to be a valid 160-bit number, or else it can be rejected for syntax reasons by the EL
